original: Ehnmark, Erland Jacob, lektor, Skara, f. 1/10/03 i Härnösand av kyr-koh. Isac E. o. Magda Markgren. G. 34 m. Eva Sandström. Barn: Monica f. 37, Agneta 41. — Stud:ex. i Härnösand 22, fil. kand. i Upps. 26, fil. mag. 28, fil. Hc. 31, fil. dr 35, arkeol. kurs v. Sv. inst. i Rom 30. Res. t. Ital. o. Frankr. 30, Tyskl., Tjeckoslov. o. Österr. 31, Engl. o. Frankr. 32, Engl. 34. Doc. i relig:hist. v. Upps. univ. 37, uppf. på andra försl :rumm. t. prof. i relågionshist. där 39, uppeh. den m. samma prof. v. Sthlms högsk. fören. föreläsn iskyldigh. 39, examina-tor i rehgrhist. i Upps. 38-40. Tim-lär. v. Upps. ensk. lärov. o. priv:-gymn. 32-34 o. 37-38, e. o. ämneslär. där 34-37, e. o. adj. v. Upps. h. a. 1. 38-40, lektor i latin o. grek. v. Skara h. a. 1. sed. 41. Skr.: The Idea of God in Homer (gradiavh. 35), Anthro-pomorphism and Miracle (39), Namn-o. sakreg. t. A. Hägerströms rom:-rättsl. arb. (41) samt upps. i tidskr.
translated: Ehnmark, Erland Jacob, lecturer in Skara, born on October 1st, 1903 in Härnösand to parish priest Isac E. and Magda Markgren. Married in 1934 to Eva Sandström. Children: Monica (born 1937) and Agneta (born 1941). He completed his high school education in Härnösand in 1922, received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Uppsala University in 1926, a Master of Arts degree in 1928, a licentiate degree in philosophy in 1931, and a Doctorate in Philosophy in 1935. He took an archaeology course at the Swedish Institute in Rome in 1930 and traveled to Italy and France the same year, to Germany, Czechoslovakia, and Austria in 1931, and to England and France in 1932 and 1934. He became a docent in religious history at Uppsala University in 1937, was considered for the position of professor of religious history there in 1939, and spent the same year with the same professor at the Stockholm College Association giving lectures. He was an examiner in the history of religions at Uppsala University from 1938-1940. He taught part-time at Uppsala private high schools and gyms from 1932-1934 and 1937-1938, was an associate professor from 1934-1937, associate professor at Uppsala University from 1938-1940, and lecturer in Latin and Greek at Skara High School from 1941 onwards. He wrote "The Idea of God in Homer" (doctoral dissertation from 1935), "Anthropomorphism and Miracle" (1939), "Titles and Subject Index to A. Hägerström's Work in Roman Law" (1941), and articles in various journals.
